Daniel & I talked about this on the podcast yesterday and the idea that the AI cycle is maturing is genuinely hard to take seriously once you look at where the real data actually lives. 

90% of the world‚Äôs enterprise data sits behind a firewall & has never been ingested, trained on or optimized for AI systems. The compute required to bring that private data into AI workflows is exponentially larger than anything we have used for public internet training because every company needs its own training runs, its own retrieval pipelines, its own security layers & its own production inference stack.

None of that has happened at scale yet. We are still in the phase where enterprises are figuring out how to structure their data, how to secure it & how to deploy models safely. The infrastructure needed to support that transition is far bigger than the footprint hyperscalers have built so far & even they are admitting they cannot energize capacity fast enough to meet enterprise demand.

We are still so early.

$BMNR just became the first large-cap crypto company to issue a dividend. 

They also reported $328M in FY25 profit with EPS of $13.39.

I don‚Äôt think folks talk enough about how important management is in the stocks they own & $GOOGL is the perfect case study. 

They acquired 40K $NVDA chips before TPU deployment went mainstream in 2014 & paired that decision with the $400M DeepMind acquisition. That combination created a foundation that allowed them to understand model training, infrastructure demands & the direction of the new digital economy before anyone else was even paying attention.

This is the reason Google continues to hold a meaningful lead in AI capabilities even though the market has spent the past year trying to lump them into the same ‚ÄúGenAI vulnerable‚Äù bucket that has weighed on $ADBE. 

That is what strong management actually looks like when it has the ability to see the next curve before the market can price it & to commit to that direction even when the noise suggests something else.

Not exactly the screen you want to wake up to.

Volatility like we‚Äôve seen in growthland over the past couple of weeks forces investors to separate the noise of the moment from the narrative of the cycle. 

The market is built to pressure-test conviction & expose anyone who confuses short-term discomfort with long-term danger.

It forces you to confront whether you actually own a thesis or whether you were just renting price action & every time we go through these periods, conviction gets redistributed to the investors who stay anchored to fundamentals while the noise overwhelms everyone else.

Corrections don‚Äôt change a secular trend but they‚Äôre what keep the cycle healthy. And yes, I‚Äôm hedged right now but that doesn‚Äôt mean I doubt the long-term. It simply means I‚Äôm respecting the short-term while the secular trend under it remains fully intact.

For anyone calling me a permabull, I‚Äôm a long-term thematic investor who also respects near-term volatility

I‚Äôve been hedged since $QQQ broke below its 50-day because I‚Äôm wearing my technical hat right now but nothing about the supercycle has changed in the past month. Only the noise has.

Wild watching AI bears celebrate a 5% pullback after missing a 60% rally the past couple years when this pullback has nothing to do with AI. 

It‚Äôs being driven by two forces that are completely unrelated to AI fundamentals: the breakdown in crypto & the sudden repricing of the December Fed meeting after the BLS decision.

This is macro noise & it doesn‚Äôt change the supercycle trend.
